titleproper.value:
Guide to the Rea Irvin drawings
                    <num>1977.253</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-11-10T11:26-0500</date>

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Rea Irvin drawings, 1977.253, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

Rea Irvin (1881-1972) was born in San Francisco, CA, where he studied for six months at the Hopkins Art Institute. He moved to New York, N.Y. at the age of 25 and soon began contributing his art regularly to 
                <emph render="italic">Cosmopolitan</emph> magazine and the humorous weekly 
                <emph render="italic">Life</emph>. He later became the first art editor of 
                <emph render="italic">The New Yorker</emph>. Between the years 1925 and 1958, hundreds of Irvin's illustrations and cartoons were published in 
                <emph render="italic">The New Yorker</emph>, and his art adorned the covers of 169 issues of the magazine. Irvin also created the iconic character of Eustace Tilley, a fashionable gentleman with a monocle and top hat who, from 1925 to 2000, appeared on the cover of 
                <emph render="italic">The New Yorker</emph> every year except 1994. Irvin also developed 
                <emph render="italic">The New Yorker</emph>'s signature type style.

Original cartoon drawings by Rea Irvin, created during the period 1910 to 1920 and presumably published in the weekly magazine 
                <emph render="italic">Life</emph>. Handwritten transcriptions of the captions that accompanied the cartoons in publication are also featured underneath the original drawings, and typed transcriptions of the captions are printed on the versos. The cartoons make references to several national and international events of the early 20th century, and are also puncuated with prevailing American social and cultural attitudes of the time.
